abstract: New Jersey school district that encompasses West Windsor and Plainsboro has found itself divided largely along racial lines following call from Superintendent David Aderhold for more holistic approach to learning that focuses less rigidly on grades, citing mental health concerns; many Asian-American parents in community object to change, viewing it as 'dumbing down' of curriculum, whereas many white parents support shift.
lead_paragraph: A superintendent’s letter advocating a “whole child” approach to learning revealed a fissure that broke down roughly along racial lines, with white parents on one side and Asian-Americans on the other.

headline.main: New Jersey School District Eases Pressure on Students, Baring an Ethnic Divide
headline.print_headline: District Eases Pressure on Students, Baring an Ethnic Divide

snippet: A superintendent’s letter advocating a “whole child” approach to learning revealed a fissure that broke down roughly along racial lines, with white parents on one side and Asian-Americans on the other.
